text: ‚Ä¢ Population is a collection of all items of interest (N). ‚Ä¢ Sample is a subset of a population (n) . ‚Ä¢ Parameter ‚Äì It is a value that refers to a population.  ‚Ä¢ Statistics ‚Äì It is a value that refers to a sample.

author: @manikaransingh3234
text: Hi @krish Naik, Your efforts in this complete DS/ML field are remarkable for the people with fewer resources. However, I may have found a mistake in this video or maybe it's just that I'm not thinking it right! In the end, you state that population mean will always be greater than the sample mean, I don't think this is a must hold for every sample. I mean wouldn't it depend on the sample we have taken? let's say we have a population of 6 people and heights are as follows- 6,6,6,3,3,3(in ft), Now if our sample is the first three people then the sample mean will be 6 and the population mean will always be somewhere around 4, right?

author: @shashishankar1352
text: Really appreciate your efforts. One thing which I want to raise out that statement "population mean is always greater than sample mean" is not correct. It depends how sampling has been done. Say population set is {1,2,5,3,7,8} and sample set is {5,7,8} as subset of population set. So here mean of sample is greater than mean of population.
